newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Petroecuador says Maxus accepts joint-venture.
newsitem.headline: Petroecuador says Maxus accepts joint-venture.

text.p: Petroecuador said Thursday that U.S. firm Maxus Energy Corp has agreed to alter contracts to run its Ecuadoran oil operations as a joint-venture with the state-owned firm.

"The representatives of the contractor have agreed to modify, in common agreement with Petroecuador, the afore-mentioned services contract to a joint-venture contract, with the object of agreeing terms and conditions of the new contract," Petroecuador announced.
"Both parties commit themselves to signing the modified contract in at most 30 days from the present date," the company said in a statement.
It added that the contractual changes will cover the operation of the Bogi-Capiron and Tivacuno fields in Ecuador's Amazon region.
The communique was signed by Petroecuador's executive president Patricio Lopez and Maxus representative John Schmid.

Ecuador's government announced late Tuesday that it was banning Maxus, owned by Argentina's YPF SA, from continuing its operations in Ecuador until it reached a joint-venture deal to share output with Petroecuador.
